author: jof
title: skinny & stragly
review:
Another 45p freebie with a newspaper

My son ranted & raved that this was the must have set of the collection, but I am disappointed by it.  Its all thin & scrawny

Pros:
it has 1 wierd fishtail part on the tail and a couple of strange eyes. These seem to be like the old light & sound light covers, but with a peg on the bottom of them.
A few odds of light green, but nothing special

Cons:
Doesn't live up to my sons hype
Very thin & skinny, doesn't look big enough to devour a diver.
End part of tail is on technic grey pin, so wobbles around & won't stay in place

author: richselby
title: Swoosh Tailed Sea Monster
review:
There's no getting away from the fact your average Lego model is somewhat angular and blocky. But with this Atlantis Piranha, the curvy swooshy tail is a delight. Made with three curvy tubes linked by Technics pins, the tail can pieces can be rotated independently. The curved sharp dorsal fin is an added bonus.

The set falls apart (figuratively, not literally) at the front. The mouth looks too big for the fish's body,and it lacks an upper jaw.  That would make it a pretty useless piranha. Still, the round treasure key more than compensated for the missing upper jaw in my 5 yr old son's mind.

Given that the set was a freebie with a newspaper, I'd say it was unbeatable value for money. And it you obtain a few sets and link the tails together, you'd have an awesome sea-snake type beastie.

author: AETerry
title: Piranha Review! I have half a head sir!
review:
All that's needed is for these to be sold where people can buy them up in multiples to create a piranha swarm. I got mine through e-bay and it wasn't that bad of a price to pick up.

 

Now to burst the bubble of those who are getting excited by this little set....

 

I was very thrilled with the idea of a Lego Piranha utilizing the Atlantis color scheme for their creatures. The main body is built well and the tail isn't bad, provided you don't mind the grey connecting piece that will cause the tail to spin a bit.

 

My problem with this set comes with the head of the creature. And it's with the jaw... the design build only has the lower jaw, there's no upper jaw and causes the build to not look right or complete. That feature greatly detracts from the overall enjoyment of this set.

 

It's a small set that comes in a polybag, experienced builders will know not to get their hopes up on complex builds. For those in the UK it was free with the purchase of a newspaper. But come on... it's like LEGO blew it with this set and model.

author: Munken
title: A Bag of Menace
review:
This little polybag and the rest of the Mirror promotion has marked my return to LEGO, I grew up in Classic Space times and since growing up, my love of lego was from a distance - often getting a bit annoyed by the growing use of HUGE pieces, like the <b>nearly-a-complete-dragon</b> piece. 

I saw this promotion and figured I'd get the polybags and thought they'd be great little gifts for my (then) newborn son when he got older and I was very happy to see the brick-built creature of this polybag. 

For an old timer this set also has a bunch of exciting parts, but I'm tainted by my 20 years away from LEGOâ€¦

I agree that this looks a bit odd with just a lower jaw and it doesn't look that much like a piranha, but it's a magnificent little sea monster with all the swooshability of a spaceship, so I got two to gang up.
